awd_titl_txt: GOALI:  Laser Forming of Metal Foam with Controlled Dimensional and Mechanical Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project investigates a novel process for laser forming of metal foam.  Metal foam has shown great potential in industrial applications by virtue of its excellent shock absorption properties and light weight. Metal foam is most economically manufactured in flat panel format and then bent as required in particular applications. The high structural rigidity due to its cellular geometry, however, makes metal foam prone to cell wall crushing and cracking when mechanically bent. Laser forming, on the other hand, has shown the capability of shaping solid metal plates without applying mechanical forces nor requiring dies.  Knowledge developed for laser forming of solid metal plates, however, is not directly applicable to foams due to fundamental differences between solids and foam metals in their response to laser irradiation and deformation. The success of this project is expected to enable the design and fabrication of innovative engineering components that incorporate low-density metal foam to significantly enhance component performance or introduce groundbreaking functionalities.  The PI's strong support from a key industrial partner could lead to a rapid development of industry applications of these components with broad societal impact including enhanced safety, reduced weight and fuel consumption for a wide range of industries including automotive, aerospace, and defense.  Underrepresented students will be recruited, and high school students and STEM teachers from neighborhood schools will be engaged in an innovative combination of "reach out" and "let in" activities.

The project aims to develop a fundamental understanding of the thermo-mechanical mechanisms that govern laser forming of low-density metal foam, determine how the forming mechanisms contribute to the formation of defects such as buckled cells and micro-cracks at large bending angles. The fundamental understanding will allow mitigation of the defects, control of dimensional accuracy and improvement mechanical properties in bent products, and quantify the above phenomena by establishing predictive capabilities.  Laser forming experiments will be performed and results quantified. The formation of micro-cracks, buckled cells and melted material at large bending angles will be analyzed. The experimental results will validate thermal-mechanical numerical models.  This project is expected to considerably advance the understanding of interactions between laser irradiation and low-density metal foam using a fundamental approach to both simulation and experimental analysis.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Metal foam is light in weight and excellent in shock absorbing, among other attractive properties. Its cellular structure, however, leads to high bending rigidity and premature fracture if mechanically bent. Building on its success in solid materials, laser forming has proven to be feasible in bending metal foam. Due to structural variations in metal foam, it is essential to develop predictive capability of the process.  Equivalent, Kelvin-Cell and micro CT scanned geometric models were investigated for their capabilities and performance in finite element analysis (Fig. Models).  Considering the laser energy absorbing behavior by the foam structure, a new laser forming mechanism, modified temperature gradient mechanism (mTGM), was proposed and experimentally and numerically validated (Fig. MTGM).  

The investigation was extended to sandwich structures, where a metal foam core is sandwiched between solid facesheets. The feasibility was demonstrated under a range of process conditions. The thermal and mechanical conditions at the core/facesheets interfaces were focused on and properly modeled (Fig. Sandwich), leading to improved understanding of temperature gradients and mechanical response in the facesheets and core. In addition, the investigation was extended from 2D to 3D shaping.  Both bowl and saddle shapes (Fig. 3D), the two most fundamental non-Euclidean geometries, were investigated under very different process conditions. It was further shown that the mechanisms of laser-induced 3D bending are similar to laser forming of 2D geometries, but laser scan paths and path length play an important role. 

The compressive behavior of metal foam before and after laser forming were thoroughly investigated. Uniaxial quasi-static compression tests were performed to investigate the process effect on stress-strain response. To simulate the crushing of metal foam under practical scenarios, dynamic impact tests were conducted using a modified Charpy impact test (Fig. Impact) to study the energy absorbing ability of laser formed metal foam under different impact velocities (Fig, Velocities). The cell surface and cell structure after impact were investigated to study the effect of laser forming and impact speeds on the energy absorbing ability of metal foam.  Due to variations in cell size and shape as well as cell wall thickness in metal foam, it is difficult to predict process failure in automated laser forming.  A machine learning approach based on infrared cameras and digital image correlation sensor data was explored.  Physics-based feature extraction and feature dimensionality reduction and separability maximization were carried out.  Several classifiers were investigated in terms of their misclassification rates and training time.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Y. Lawrence Yao

Images (1 of )
  • Typical color contours of the (a) equivalent model, (b) Kelvin-cell model and (c) voxel model during a laser scan. Legends are omitted since the color contours are used for a qualitative comparison.
    131.Bucher, T., Bolger, C., Zhang, M., Chen, C.J., Yao, Y.L., �Effect of Geometrical Modeling on Prediction of Laser-Induced Heat Transfer in Metal Foam,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, Vol. 138, Dec. 2016, 121008-1, DOI: 10.1115/1.4033927.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Models
  • Cross-section of a foam specimen after 5 laser scans at 180 W and 10 mm/s. The laser was scanned into the page. The white arrows show where cell walls were bent during laser forming, indicating that the foam cannot withstand high compressive stresses.
    139.Bucher, T., Young, A., Zhang, M., Chen, C.J., Yao, Y.L., �Thermally Induced Mechanical Response of Metal Foam during Laser Forming,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, Vol. 140, No. 4, 2018, 041004-1, DOI: 10.1115/1.4038995.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    MTGM
  • Simulated temperature distributions at a cross-section (yz-plane) right as the laser passes, both in the entire sandwich (equivalent sandwich model) and in an isolated facesheet.
    141.Bucher, T., Cardenas, S., Verma, R., Li, W., Yao, Y.L., �Laser Forming of Sandwich Panels with Metal Foam Core,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, 140(11):111015-111015-12, 2018, doi: 10.1115/1.4040959.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Sandwich
  • Saddle shape after 288 scans at a laser spot size of D = 4 mm with scan speed of v = 30 mm/s.
    146.Bucher, T., Finn, C., Verma, R., Li, W., Yao, Y.L., �3D Laser Forming of Metal Foam Sandwich Panels,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, August 2020, 142(8): 081008, DOI: 10.1115/1.4047242.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    3D
  • The Charpy impact tester. A 25-mm diameter and 30-mm high foam specimen is placed inside the adaptor, with direct contact between the moving striker and a fixed back support. The adaptor is set in the slot of the Charpy test machine.
    148.Zhang, T., Liu, Y., Ashmore, N., Li, W., Yao, Y.L., �Effect of Laser Forming on the Energy Absorbing Behavior of Metal Foams,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, January 2022, Vol. 144(1), 011001-1, DOI: 10.1115/1.4051285.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Impact
  • Crush band development after impact from the top surface at speed of (a) v=1.22 m/s, (b) v=1.10 m/s, (c) v=0.97 m/s, (d) v=0.83 m/s, and (e) v=0.66 m/s.
    Zhang, T., Liu, Y., Ashmore, N., Li, W., Yao, Y.L., �Effect of Laser Forming on the Energy Absorbing Behavior of Metal Foams,� ASME Trans. J. of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, January 2022, Vol. 144(1), 011001-1, DOI: 10.1115/1.4051285.
    Copyrighted
